description: From Middle English erthen, urthen, from Old English eorþen, *yrþen, *ierþen (“made of earth”), from Proto-Germanic *irþīnaz, equivalent to earth +‎ -en (adjectival suffix). Cognate with Dutch aarden (“earthen”), German irden (“earthen”).

adjectives.description: earthen (comparative more earthen, superlative most earthen)

examples: A hundred earthen dwellings stood on the margin of the lake  […]

entries.meaning: Made of clay (especially said of pottery).
examples: ... the Godfathers and Godmothers follow into the midst of the Church, where there is a small table ready set, and on it an earthen pot ful of warme water,  […]
Will they be yours when one by one these earthen / Delights and comforts and all beauties wane? / Will they be found laid up above, illumined?

verbs.description: earthen (third-person singular simple present earthens, present participle earthening, simple past and past participle earthened)

entries.meaning: (transitive) to provide or add soil to
